title: Quick Conversion Tips & Tricks
description: Learn practical shortcuts and mental math tricks for faster number system conversions.

sections.title: Powers of 2 - Memorize These!
sections.content:
Memorizing powers of 2 makes binary conversion much faster.

**Essential Powers of 2:**
```
2⁰  = 1
2¹  = 2
2²  = 4
2³  = 8
2⁴  = 16
2⁵  = 32
2⁶  = 64
2⁷  = 128
2⁸  = 256
2⁹  = 512
2¹⁰ = 1024 (≈ 1KB)
2¹⁶ = 65536 (≈ 64KB)
```

**Quick Recognition:**
• 1024 ≈ 1 thousand (1K)
• 1,048,576 ≈ 1 million (1M)
• 1,073,741,824 ≈ 1 billion (1G)

**Why memorize?**
• Instantly recognize 128 = 10000000
• Know that 256 needs 8 bits
• Quick binary-decimal mental math

sections.title: Binary-Hex Quick Conversion
sections.content:
The fastest conversion: Binary ↔ Hex using 4-bit chunks.

**Memorize the 4-bit table:**
```
0000=0  0100=4  1000=8  1100=C
0001=1  0101=5  1001=9  1101=D
0010=2  0110=6  1010=A  1110=E
0011=3  0111=7  1011=B  1111=F
```

**Quick Method:**
• Binary → Hex: Group by 4, convert each group
• Hex → Binary: Replace each hex digit with 4 bits

**Example: 11010110 → Hex**
• Group: 1101 0110
• Convert: D 6
• Result: D6

**Example: 3F → Binary**
• 3 → 0011
• F → 1111
• Result: 00111111

**Speed Tip:** This is WAY faster than going through decimal!

sections.title: Mental Math Shortcuts
sections.content:
**1. Doubling Trick (Decimal → Binary)**
For small numbers, keep dividing by 2:
• 13 → 6.5 (1) → 3 (0) → 1.5 (1) → 0 (1)
• Read remainders backwards: 1101

**2. Hex Digit Recognition**
Instantly recognize common patterns:
• FF = 255 (all bits set in a byte)
• 80 = 128 (highest bit only)
• 7F = 127 (all bits except highest)

**3. Octal via Binary**
Group by 3 bits instead of 4:
• Binary 101110 → 10 110 → 2 6 → Octal 26

**4. Quick Decimal to Hex**
For numbers under 256:
• 100 ÷ 16 = 6 remainder 4 → 64₁₆
• 200 ÷ 16 = 12 remainder 8 → C8₁₆

**5. Recognize Boundaries**
• 255 = FF = 11111111 (max byte)
• 256 = 100₁₆ = 100000000₂
• 4096 = 1000₁₆ = 1000000000000₂

exercises.problem: What power of 2 is closest to 1000?
exercises.explanation: 2¹⁰ = 1024, which is close to 1000 (this is why 1KB ≈ 1000 bytes)

questions.explanation: 2⁸ = 256. This is the number of values in one byte (0-255).
hints: It's the number of values in a byte

questions.questionText: Converting between binary and hex is faster than converting between binary and decimal.
questions.explanation: True. Binary-hex conversion is direct (4 bits per hex digit), while binary-decimal requires calculation.
FF = 255, the maximum value for one byte. This is worth memorizing!
hints: It's all bits set in a byte

questions.questionText: Memorizing powers of 2 makes binary conversions significantly faster.
questions.explanation: True. Knowing powers of 2 lets you quickly convert and estimate without calculation.

questions.questionText: For quick binary to octal conversion, you group bits by:
questions.explanation: Octal is base 8 = 2³, so you group binary digits by 3s. Hex uses groups of 4 because 16 = 2⁴.
